title: More construction in the North East but skills shortage bites
text:
More construction in the North East but skills shortage bites Planning and regulation, financial constraints and tender prices are also proving problematic for the region's construction companies Share A building in Newcastle's £350m Science Central development is set to be completed this summer (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Workloads are on the up but the skills shortage continues to challenge North East construction firms’ ability to carry out contracts. 
That is the main finding of the latest Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) Construction Market Survey , covering the first quarter of 2017. 
The start of the year saw 28% more respondents report an increase in construction and infrastructure workload – up from 26% in the last quarter of 2016 – and 48% expect activity to remain positive and are expecting a rise in workloads over the coming year. 
However, the shortage of skilled labour persists in the region’s sector, with 52% of contributors citing it as a factor impacting the performance of local businesses working in the industry, hindering the delivery of schemes in the North East. 
Meanwhile, financial constraints are still the most significant obstacle to growth with 79% of respondents citing this as an issue, up from 74% at the end of last year. Constructio the new Travelodge hotel that is being built on the site of the former BT offices next door to the Copthorne Hotel on the Newcastle quayside (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Planning and regulation is also a significant impediment to growth, with 57% of respondents citing this as an obstacle, a rise of 6%. 
Tender prices are also expected to rise in the next 12 months, which might result in rising costs and shrinking profit margins. 
Only 26% of the firms who took part in the survey are anticipating a rise in profits over the coming year, compared with 29% back in Q4 2016. 
The survey also looked at different types of property being built in the North East in the first quarter of the year and the pace of growth increased across the majority of sectors. 
In all, 38% of respondents said they are seeing an increase in private housing, up from 36% in Q4 2016, and over 25% more contributors reported a rise in Infrastructure activity - including rail, road and energy schemes. 
The private commercial sector was the only property type that did not see an increase in output. Construction of new shopping centre in Framwellgate, Durham (Photo: newcastle chronicle) 
Geoff White, RICS policy manager for the North and Midlands, added: “The skills shortage has clear implications for the future of the North East, where major plans are being developed to improve transport infrastructure through Transport for the North. 
“Better connectivity is crucial to investment and economic growth plans. It would be a disaster for any government’s plan to rebalance the UK economy if a shortage of skilled labour was allowed to hold things back. This is a vital issue that the new metro mayors should tackle urgently after the elections on 4 May. 
“We have highlighted the skills shortage issue in our soon-to-be-published General Election manifesto which calls for commitments from all parties. 
“This is a major Brexit issue too. Our research estimates EU nationals account for 8% of the industry workforce which is almost 200,000 workers. 
“With UK construction already facing a chronic skills shortage, it could threaten some of the country’s biggest infrastructure and construction projects, as well as their respective pipelines.” Like us on Facebook
